docs.lead_paragraph: Repetitive motions, like working on a computer keyboard or cutting meat, have long been known to contribute to repetitive stress injuries. But now, a new study finds, psychological factors may also play a role. Researchers writing in The British Medical Journal said they found a link between forearm pain and job dissatisfaction. Other forms of psychological stress were also linked to the pain, said the researchers, from the University of Manchester in England.

headline.main: Linking Repetitive Stress and Job Stress

docs.abstract: New study finds that job dissatisfaction and other kinds of psychological stress may play role in contributing to repetitive stress injuries (S)
